posts.name: Nadav
posts.cooked:
Elastic Logo 5583×1280 234 KB

Elastic Logo 5583×1280 234 KB

Elastic Logo 5583×1280 234 KB

I’m happy to begin initial 2025 beta testing for Elastic. For those who aren’t familiar with Elastic, it’s a Flutter driver dashboard that acts as a drop in replacement for Shuffleboard, with a nicer UI, network optimizations, and more customizability. Elastic was initially released last year, and I was blown away by the community response.

2025 Demo Layout 1920×950 228 KB

2025 Demo Layout 1920×950 228 KB

2025 Demo Layout 1920×950 228 KB

Overall, not much on the outside. The interface and UX is extremely similar, but the differences lie in all the tiny additions and new features.

There’s lots of new improvements to explore, so let’s begin:

The most significant change for Elastic in 2025 isn’t even in the actual app, it’s how the app is installed. On the GitHub releases (linked at the bottom of the post), there are now 2 download options for Windows: a portable option (the only option during 2024 season) and now the installer option. Instead of having to manually extract a zip file and create shortcuts, an installer can be ran to install the app and create desktop shortcuts. The portable version will remain available for teams who wish to to continue using it.

This is only available on Windows as of right now.

The Alerts widget (which is also being added to WPILib in 2025) is extremely useful for displaying any issues or potential warnings. However, if you want to post a temporary status update or grab the user’s attention when the widget isn’t visible, there isn’t an easy way to do so. Which is why there is now the ability to send notifications from robot code.

Along with this is the introduction of ElasticLib, which is a 1 file library that can be dropped into a robot project to allow sending notifications. Here’s an example of how to send an error notification with ElasticLib:

Which will send an on-screen notification that looks like this:

As of right now, this is only supported in Java, but contributions for a C++ port are open.

Elastic has always had the option to customize the color of the app. However, often times the color scheme generated wouldn’t match the vibrancy of the color, especially for bright colors. Now, there are many options as to how to customize the color scheme, which allows for a much wider range of colors across the app.

image 387×921 7.6 KB (There’s even more!)

image 387×921 7.6 KB

image 387×921 7.6 KB

Ever had a widget that was customized a specific way that you wanted to be able to copy onto another tab? Well you will no longer have to recreate the widget, you can now copy and paste a widget onto another tab!

copying_widget 1920×950 230 KB

copying_widget 1920×950 230 KB

copying_widget 1920×950 230 KB

pasting_widget 1920×950 11.7 KB

pasting_widget 1920×950 11.7 KB

pasting_widget 1920×950 11.7 KB

Camera streams can use up a LOT of bandwidth. While Elastic has made some measures to conserve bandwidth from the camera streams, if a camera was sending a high resolution stream at a high framerate, there wasn’t much that could be done about it.

Now, there is now the ability to change the quality (compression), resolution, and fps, allowing for low bandwidth camera streams.

image 576×871 25.6 KB

image 576×871 25.6 KB

image 576×871 25.6 KB

If you want to know more about all the small improvements made, here’s a list of all of them:

Similar to how the state management for all the draggable containers themselves were redone, the state of each individual widget was also refactored. This allows for much easier testing and fixes issues with widgets not updating after changing settings (most commonly seen with graphs).

Redid NT widget state management · Gold872/elastic-dashboard@61ec1d5 · GitHub

In a text display often times when a number was really small, it would display in scientific notation, which made it very confusing to read at times. This will no longer happen.

Exported JSON files will no longer be a 1 line hard to read mess. Now, they will be indented and should be easier to modify without using a formatter.

In addition to being able to change colors, you can now display different icons when a boolean value is true or false.

Previously the camera streams were not very efficient. When dragging a live camera widget, it would open a new http stream which sends the exact same data. Now, duplicate camera streams are shared, and are properly disposed when the widget is not visible.

Improved camera stream efficiency by Gold872 · Pull Request #37 · Gold872/elastic-dashboard · GitHub

If there’s a camera that sends an extremely high quality stream that’s using too much bandwidth, it’s now possible to lower the quality, resolution, and FPS from the server side.

Added ability to change camera stream quality by Gold872 · Pull Request #38 · Gold872/elastic-dashboard · GitHub

For situations where alerts might not be alerting enough, you can now send a notification to the dashboard via robot code. This can be helpful during pre-match setup to alert the drive team of any critical issues that arise.

Allow robot created notifications by EmeraldWither · Pull Request #48 · Gold872/elastic-dashboard · GitHub

Each new release will now include a windows installer, which makes updating significantly easier. Unfortunately due to limitations with InnoSetup, this is only available on windows.

Add windows installer by Gold872 · Pull Request #54 · Gold872/elastic-dashboard · GitHub

Wanted to duplicate a widget onto another tab? Well now that’s easier than ever! Just right click on the widget, click copy, and then paste it where you need to!

Copy & paste feature by DanPeled · Pull Request #62 · Gold872/elastic-dashboard · GitHub

If for whatever reason you rapidly connect and disconnect from your robot, the auto reconnection will not be broken once the disconnection stops.

Improved connection stability by Gold872 · Pull Request #69 · Gold872/elastic-dashboard · GitHub

In addition to changing robot size and view options on the Field widget, there’s now the option to change the color of the robot’s bumpers, and the color of trajectories.

added option to modify robot & trajectory colors by DanPeled · Pull Request #82 · Gold872/elastic-dashboard · GitHub

For the YAGSL swerve widget, if the angle that’s being displayed is offset by a constant amount, there is now the ability to add an offset so it can be displayed in the desired direction.

Swerve angle offset feature by DanPeled · Pull Request #59 · Gold872/elastic-dashboard · GitHub

The field image files have been compressed to reduce size and increase performance. The overall size of the app has been reduce by ~25%.

This also fixed the occasional flicker that’s seen when field objects are updating.

Compress field images with oxipng by Gold856 · Pull Request #103 · Gold872/elastic-dashboard · GitHub

If you have an idea or feedback, I’d love to hear it! Most of what Elastic has become today is from the support and feedback from over 1,700 users that have downloaded and used the app. Feel free to either comment on this post, or open up an issue on GitHub, I’d love to hear your ideas.

This year several features (listed on the GitHub release notes) were made by other contributors in FIRST . I’d like to thank the 3 new contributors:

@EmerqldWither

@Dan1

@gold856

Just like last year, Elastic can be downloaded from the releases page on GitHub. For windows users, there is now the option to run an installer instead of extracting a zip file. This method is recommended as it handles app locations and shortcut creation on its own.

Note for Mac Users: Settings from the 2024 version will likely not transfer when installing the 2025 version since the package name has been changed. Before installing, it is recommended to export any layouts or settings you have.

GitHub Repository : GitHub - Gold872/elastic-dashboard: A simple and modern dashboard for FRC

Documentation : Home · Gold872/elastic-dashboard Wiki · GitHub

Download : Release Elastic 2025.0.0 Beta 1 · Gold872/elastic-dashboard · GitHub

Thank you to everyone that uses Elastic as their driver dashboard. I’m looking forward to seeing how teams make use of it this season!

posts.cooked: This is a super cool update. At a technical level could you clarify how the camera quality adjustment on the dashboard side decreases bandwidth? If the compression is happening on the driver station wouldn’t the camera still be sending the full res version through the network?

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
Thanks for doing this.  Please excuse me if this is already explained somewhere, but two things I’ve seen in other dashboards but not found in Elastic are:

Multiple values on one graph, e.g. dragging them in

Customization of Field objects, e.g. to look like game pieces

posts.cooked:

Yes.

I mean this way:

posts.name: Dan Peled

posts.name: Lidor Kaplan
posts.cooked:
In that case, the desired orientation depends on the alliance color.

Red alliance view should be 180-rotated from the above screenshot.

posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: It isn’t critical for me that your alliance always downwards but if it had the option to flip it can be nice to other teams (should make it an optional)

posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: Its nice to put the field on the side so its not in the middle of the screent

posts.name: Dan Peled
posts.cooked: I’ll just add an option to rotate and u choose

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
One use case where we have a dashboard that we want the field to be vertical is to give a quick overview to someone who doesn’t live and breath FRC . (Could be a new programmer or new drive team applicant, a school administrator, a parent, or a potential sponsor.)

For a field-relative drive, “joystick up” is away from the alliance wall. It’s nice to give someone a sim where joystick up moves the virtual robot up, right goes right, etc.

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked:
sokoloff:

For a field-relative drive, “joystick up” is away from the alliance wall. It’s nice to give someone a sim where joystick up moves the virtual robot up, right goes right, etc.

This would be my preferred view in every field2d display, it would be great if this also existed in glass and AdvantageScope. Driver station perspective makes sense for most things to me.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: Orientation rotation (in 90° increments) exists in the Odometry tab of the 4.0 Beta of Advantage Scope. Not sure about older versions.

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked: Yep, this feature has been supported since 2023.

posts.name: Nadav
posts.cooked:
Initially I also thought it happened on the dashboard end, but it’s on the server side. Essentially what happens is parameters are passed into the HTTP request, and the logic for compression and resolution changing is done on the server end.

Introducing Elastic: A simple and modern alternative to Shuffleboard Programming

link_counts.title: Introducing Elastic: A simple and modern alternative to Shuffleboard

posts.name: Nadav
posts.cooked:
That’s interesting, I’ll try to look into it but I’ll need some help with debugging on your side

First, open the app on the latest version (it can be installer or portable, doesn’t make a difference), then leave it open for a bit, and then close it.

Then, in file explorer if you type %AppData%/com.gold872/elastic_dashboard there should be a file called “elastic-log.txt”, could you send that so I can look into it?

Another piece of information that would be helpful is the system summary. In the search at the bottom of the screen, type in “System Information”, and send a screenshot of the information under “System Type” and “Processor”

posts.name: Christopher Coleman
posts.cooked: Could the field be mirrored based on what alliance the DS has selected/given so that it doesn’t have to be changed manually?
